[1] Accumulation of abdominal VF is an independent risk factor for obesity-related metabolic abnormalities . [2] VF can be partitioned into intraperitoneal and extraperitoneal compartments using anatomical reference points such as the kidneys and ascending and descending colon . [3] The release of free fatty acids (FFAs) from the intraperitoneal depot drains into the portal system, interfering with hepatic glucose metabolism , leading to hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance. [4] Extraperitoneal fat, on the other hand, drains into the systemic circulation and thus is not directly involved in hepatic glucose metabolism . [1] Absolute quantification of fat mass is achieved by MRI, whereas tissue-specific glucose metabolism can be noninvasively assessed using positron emission tomography (PET) with [18F]-fluorodeoxyglucose ([18F]-FDG) . [2] Combined PET/MRI thus provides anatomical and functional information on specific tissue compartments.
